title: I left the North for London in the Eighties and have rarely looked back
text:
As a study finds the 'gene drain' affects regional industrial areas, James Brown reflects on what made him leave the North for London

I left the North in 1986 quite simply because I had no choice.

I grew up in Headingley, Leeds and, after leaving school at 18, wanted more than what the city had to offer me which, at that point, was precisely nothing. I knew two people my age who had jobs, the rest were either in further education or on the dole. I wanted a job writing about music and the only place I could do that full time was London, where the NME, Sounds, ZigZag, Melody Maker and Record Mirror were based.

Mine isn’t quite the story told by a research paper out yesterday, which found that...
description: As a study finds the 'gene drain' affects regional industrial areas, James Brown reflects on what made him leave the North for London
